story_title: London's Stinky Crisis That Changed Sanitation Forever
original_story: [dramatic] You won't believe this: in 1858, London was engulfed by the Great Stink! The Thames became a putrid cesspool, with raw sewage flowing into the river. Imagine a city gripped by a foul odor so intense it drove Parliament out of their sessions! This smelly crisis led to the development of a revolutionary sewer system designed by Joseph Bazalgette. He transformed public health, reducing cholera outbreaks by over 90%. Who knew a bad smell could spark such monumental change? [pause:0.5s]

synchronized_prompts.image_prompt: Wide shot of a foggy, polluted Thames River in 1858, with dark, swirling mists rising from the murky water. Silhouetted figures of distressed citizens clutching their noses, while the imposing architecture of Parliament looms in the background, hinting at the chaos within. Dramatic chiaroscuro lighting accentuates the grim atmosphere.
